topics.topic_name: DO ORGANISMS CREATE EXACT COPIES OF THEMSELVES?
key_concepts: Reproduction at its most basic level will involve making copies of the blueprints of body design.
Chromosomes in the nucleus of a cell contain information for inheritance of features in the form of DNA molecules.
A basic event in reproduction is the creation of a DNA copy.
DNA copying is accompanied by the creation of additional cellular apparatus.
DNA copies generated will be similar, but may not be identical to the original.
The inbuilt tendency for variation during reproduction is the basis for evolution.
questions: Why is DNA copying important in the process of reproduction?
What role does DNA play in inheritance of features?
Explain why the copies of DNA made during reproduction are not always identical.
How does inaccurate DNA copying lead to variation?
Why are variations important for the continuation of species?

key_concepts: The consistency of DNA copying during reproduction is important for the maintenance of body design features.
Reproduction is linked to the stability of populations of species.
Niches can change because of reasons beyond the control of the organisms.
If some variations are present in individuals of a population, there is a chance for survival under altered conditions.
Variation is useful for the survival of species over time.
questions: Why is variation necessary for survival of a species in changing environments?
Give one example where variation has helped organisms survive.
How does variation provide stability to a population?
Explain why variation is considered the basis of evolution.
In what way is variation useful for long-term survival of species?

topics.topic_name: MODES OF REPRODUCTION USED BY SINGLE ORGANISMS
key_concepts: The modes by which various organisms reproduce depend on the body design of the organisms.
All the modes of reproduction discussed allow new generations to be created from a single individual.
This is known as asexual reproduction.
questions: Differentiate between asexual and sexual reproduction.
What is meant by asexual reproduction? Give two examples.
Why are offspring formed by asexual reproduction considered clones?
State one advantage and one disadvantage of asexual reproduction.
How does asexual reproduction ensure rapid multiplication of organisms?

key_concepts: For unicellular organisms, cell division or fission leads to the creation of new individuals.
In Amoeba, the splitting of the two cells during division can take place in any plane.
In Leishmania, binary fission occurs in a definite orientation in relation to the whip-like structure.
Plasmodium divides into many daughter cells simultaneously by multiple fission.
questions: What is binary fission? Give two examples.
How does binary fission in Amoeba differ from that in Leishmania?
Define multiple fission with one example.
Explain how Plasmodium reproduces.
What type of reproduction is shown by unicellular organisms like Amoeba?

key_concepts: Spirogyra simply breaks up into smaller pieces upon maturation.
These fragments grow into new individuals.
Many multicellular organisms cannot reproduce by simple fragmentation due to specialised cells and tissues.
questions: What is fragmentation? Name one organism that reproduces by fragmentation.
How does fragmentation differ from regeneration?
Why can't complex multicellular organisms reproduce by fragmentation?
Explain reproduction by fragmentation in Spirogyra.
State one limitation of fragmentation as a mode of reproduction.

key_concepts: Simple animals like Hydra and Planaria can be cut into many pieces and each piece grows into a complete organism.
Regeneration is carried out by specialised cells which proliferate and form various cell types and tissues.
Regeneration is not the same as reproduction.
questions: Explain regeneration with an example.
How does Planaria reproduce by regeneration?
Why is regeneration not considered the same as reproduction?
Which specialised cells help in regeneration?
Give one difference between regeneration and fragmentation.

key_concepts: In Hydra, a bud develops as an outgrowth due to repeated cell division at one specific site.
Buds develop into tiny individuals and when fully mature, detach from the parent body and become new independent individuals.
questions: What is budding? Name one organism that reproduces this way.
Describe budding in Hydra with a diagram.
How is budding different from fission?
Give one advantage of budding as a mode of reproduction.
Which organism shows both regeneration and budding?

key_concepts: In many plants, parts like root, stem and leaves develop into new plants under appropriate conditions.
This property is used in layering or grafting to grow plants like sugarcane, roses, or grapes.
Plants raised by vegetative propagation can bear flowers and fruits earlier than those produced from seeds.
Vegetative propagation is useful for plants such as banana, orange, rose and jasmine that have lost the capacity to produce seeds.
All plants produced are genetically similar enough to the parent plant to have all its characteristics.
In tissue culture, new plants are grown by removing tissue or cells from the growing tip of a plant in artificial medium.
questions: What is vegetative propagation? Give two examples.
State two advantages of vegetative propagation.
Name two plants which are grown by grafting.
Why is tissue culture important in agriculture?
How does vegetative propagation ensure genetically identical plants?

key_concepts: In Rhizopus, tiny blob-on-a-stick structures (sporangia) contain cells or spores.
Spores can develop into new Rhizopus individuals.
Spores are covered by thick walls that protect them until they come into contact with a moist surface and begin to grow.
questions: Explain spore formation in Rhizopus with a diagram.
Why do spores have thick walls?
What conditions help spores germinate?
List one advantage of spore formation.
Name one other organism that reproduces by spore formation.

key_concepts: Sexual reproduction depends on the involvement of two individuals.
Both sexes, males and females, are needed to produce new generations.
Sexual mode of reproduction allows more variation to be generated.
questions: What are the advantages of sexual reproduction over asexual reproduction?
Why does sexual reproduction create more variation?
Why are two sexes required for sexual reproduction?
State one disadvantage of sexual reproduction compared to asexual reproduction.
How does sexual reproduction contribute to evolution?

subtopics.subtopic_name: Why the Sexual Mode of Reproduction?
key_concepts: DNA copying cannot be absolutely accurate, and resultant errors are a source of variations.
Combining variations from two individuals creates new combinations of variants.
Specialised organs produce germ-cells with half the number of chromosomes through meiosis.
Fusion of germ-cells restores the chromosome number in the new generation.
One germ-cell is motile (male gamete) and the other is large with food stores (female gamete).
questions: Why does sexual reproduction produce variation?
What is the role of meiosis in sexual reproduction?
Why are gametes produced with half the chromosome number?
What happens when two gametes fuse?
How do male and female gametes differ in size and function?

key_concepts: The reproductive parts of angiosperms are located in the flower.
Stamens are the male reproductive parts producing pollen grains.
Pistil is the female reproductive part consisting of ovary, style and stigma.
Fertilisation is the fusion of male and female germ-cells in the ovule to form a zygote.
Self-pollination occurs in the same flower, cross-pollination involves transfer between flowers by wind, water or animals.
After fertilisation, the ovule develops into a seed and the ovary ripens to form a fruit.
questions: What are the male and female reproductive parts of a flower?
Differentiate between self-pollination and cross-pollination.
How is pollination carried out in plants?
What changes occur in the ovary after fertilisation?
Explain how seeds and fruits are formed in flowering plants.

key_concepts: Humans use a sexual mode of reproduction.
Puberty is the period when reproductive tissues begin to mature.
Changes during puberty include hair growth, voice changes, breast development, and menstruation.
Sexual maturation ensures the body is ready for reproduction.
questions: What changes occur in boys and girls during puberty?
Define puberty. Why is it important?
Which hormones are responsible for changes during puberty?
List two physical changes in boys and two in girls at puberty.
Why does sexual maturation occur at adolescence?

key_concepts: Testes produce sperms and secrete the hormone testosterone.
Sperms are delivered through vas deferens which unites with a tube from the urinary bladder.
Prostate gland and seminal vesicles add secretions that provide nutrition and make sperm transport easier.
questions: Draw and label the human male reproductive system.
What is the function of testes?
What is the role of prostate gland?
How do sperms reach the urethra?
Which hormone is secreted by testes and what is its function?

key_concepts: Ovaries produce eggs and some hormones.
One egg is produced every month and carried through the fallopian tube to the uterus.
The fertilised egg develops into an embryo, which is implanted in the uterine lining.
The placenta facilitates exchange of nutrients, oxygen and waste between mother and embryo.
questions: Draw and label the human female reproductive system.
Where are eggs produced in females?
What happens to the egg if it is fertilised?
What is the function of placenta?
Which hormones are secreted by ovaries?

subtopics.subtopic_name: (c) What happens when the Egg is not Fertilised?
key_concepts: If the egg is not fertilised, it lives for about one day.
The uterus lining, which had thickened to receive an embryo, breaks and comes out as blood and mucous.
This cycle is known as menstruation and usually lasts for about two to eight days.
questions: What is menstruation?
How long does menstruation last in humans?
What happens to the uterus lining if fertilisation does not take place?
At what interval does menstruation occur?
Why is menstruation considered a sign of sexual maturity in girls?

key_concepts: Diseases can be sexually transmitted, e.g., gonorrhoea, syphilis, HIV-AIDS.
Contraceptive methods include mechanical barriers (condoms), hormonal pills, copper-T, and surgical methods.
Prenatal sex determination is prohibited by law to prevent female foeticide.
Population size affects standard of living; inequality worsens poor living standards.
questions: Name two sexually transmitted diseases. How can they be prevented?
List four methods of contraception.
Why is prenatal sex determination banned?
What is the importance of reproductive health?
How does population growth affect the standard of living?

key_concepts: Inheritance from the previous generation provides both a common basic body design and subtle changes for the next generation.
In asexual reproduction, offspring are very similar with only minor differences due to small inaccuracies in DNA copying.
If sexual reproduction is involved, even greater diversity will be generated.
Different individuals would have different kinds of advantages depending on the nature of variations.
Selection of variants by environmental factors forms the basis for evolutionary processes.
questions: Why do offspring of asexual reproduction show minor differences?
How does sexual reproduction increase variation compared to asexual reproduction?
Explain how variation helps a species adapt to changing environments.
Why is variation considered the raw material of evolution?
What role do environmental factors play in the selection of variations?

key_concepts: The most obvious outcome of the reproductive process remains the generation of individuals of similar design.
The rules of heredity determine the process by which traits and characteristics are reliably inherited.
questions: What is heredity?
Why do children resemble their parents?
Explain the importance of heredity in the continuity of life.
How do rules of heredity ensure stable transmission of traits?
Why is heredity essential in reproduction?

key_concepts: A child bears all the basic features of a human being but does not look exactly like its parents.
Human populations show a great deal of variation.
Free and attached earlobes are two variants found in human populations.
questions: What are inherited traits? Give an example.
Why does a child not look exactly like its parents?
Explain the difference between free and attached earlobes.
How do inherited traits differ from acquired traits?
Give one example of a visible variation in human populations.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Rules for the Inheritance of Traits - Mendel's Contributions
key_concepts: Both the father and the mother contribute practically equal amounts of genetic material to the child.
Mendel used a number of contrasting visible characters of garden peas - round/wrinkled seeds, tall/short plants, white/violet flowers.
In F1 generation, only one of the parental traits was seen, not a mixture of the two.
Two copies of factors (now called genes) controlling traits are present in sexually reproducing organisms.
Traits like ‘T' are called dominant traits, while those that behave like 't' are called recessive traits.
The tall/short trait and the round seed/wrinkled seed trait are independently inherited.
questions: What contribution did Mendel make to the study of heredity?
Why did Mendel choose pea plants for his experiments?
Explain dominant and recessive traits with examples.
What were Mendel's observations in the F1 and F2 generations?
What is meant by independent assortment of traits?

subtopics.subtopic_name: How do these Traits get Expressed?
key_concepts: Cellular DNA is the information source for making proteins in the cell.
A section of DNA that provides information for one protein is called the gene for that protein.
Genes control characteristics, or traits, through proteins such as enzymes or hormones.
Each pea plant must have two sets of all genes, one inherited from each parent.
Each gene set is present as separate independent pieces called chromosomes.
Each germ-cell takes one chromosome from each pair, and when two germ cells combine, the normal number of chromosomes is restored in the progeny.
questions: What is a gene? How does it control traits?
Explain how DNA and proteins are related in trait expression.
Why does each individual have two sets of genes?
How is the chromosome number maintained during reproduction?
What role do germ cells play in heredity?

key_concepts: Different species use very different strategies for sex determination.
In some reptiles, the temperature at which fertilised eggs are kept determines the sex of the animal.
In some animals such as snails, individuals can change sex.
In human beings, the sex of the individual is largely genetically determined.
Women have a perfect pair of sex chromosomes (XX) while men have a mismatched pair (XY).
The sex of the children will be determined by what they inherit from their father.
questions: How is sex determined in human beings?
What role do sex chromosomes play in humans?
Give two examples of sex determination in animals other than humans.
Why is the father responsible for determining the sex of the child?
How does temperature affect sex determination in some reptiles?

key_concepts: Light is a form of energy which enables us to see objects.
When light falls on a smooth polished surface like a mirror, it bounces back. This phenomenon is called reflection of light.
The angle of incidence is equal to the angle of reflection.
The incident ray, reflected ray and the normal at the point of incidence all lie in the same plane.
questions: What is reflection of light?
State the laws of reflection.
Why do we see our image in a mirror?
Define angle of incidence and angle of reflection.
Explain why the incident ray, reflected ray and the normal lie in the same plane.

key_concepts: Mirrors with curved reflecting surfaces are called spherical mirrors.
A spherical mirror may be concave (converging) or convex (diverging).
Important terms include pole, centre of curvature, radius of curvature, principal axis, principal focus and focal length.
questions: What are spherical mirrors?
Differentiate between concave and convex mirrors.
Define pole, centre of curvature and focal length.
What is the principal axis of a spherical mirror?
Explain the term principal focus.

key_concepts: Images formed by spherical mirrors depend on the position of the object.
Concave mirrors can form real or virtual images depending on object position.
Convex mirrors always form virtual, erect and diminished images.
questions: Describe image formation by a concave mirror when the object is placed at infinity.
How is the image formed by a concave mirror when the object is between F and P?
What kind of images are formed by convex mirrors?
Why are convex mirrors used as rear-view mirrors?
Draw ray diagrams for image formation in concave mirrors.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Representation of Images Formed by Spherical Mirrors Using Ray Diagrams
key_concepts: Ray diagrams help in locating images formed by spherical mirrors.
Rules: A ray parallel to the principal axis passes through the focus (concave) or appears to diverge from focus (convex).
A ray passing through the centre of curvature reflects back along the same path.
A ray passing through the focus emerges parallel to the principal axis.
questions: What are the rules for constructing ray diagrams in concave mirrors?
How can ray diagrams be used to determine image position?
Draw a ray diagram when the object is placed at the centre of curvature of a concave mirror.
Explain why a ray passing through the focus emerges parallel to the axis.
What happens when a ray passes through the centre of curvature?

subtopics.subtopic_name: Sign Convention for Reflection by Spherical Mirrors
key_concepts: Distances measured against the incident light are taken as negative.
Distances measured in the direction of incident light are positive.
Distances measured upward and perpendicular to the principal axis are positive.
Distances measured downward are negative.
questions: State the sign conventions used for spherical mirrors.
Why are distances measured opposite to incident light taken as negative?
What is the sign convention for measuring heights above the principal axis?
Give an example to show how sign convention is applied in mirrors.
Explain why focal length of a concave mirror is taken as negative.

key_concepts: Mirror formula: 1/f = 1/v + 1/u, where u = object distance, v = image distance, f = focal length.
Magnification (m) = height of image / height of object = v/u.
Magnification is negative for real images and positive for virtual images.
questions: Write the mirror formula and explain its terms.
How is magnification related to image and object distances?
What does negative magnification indicate?
Solve a numerical using the mirror formula.
Differentiate between real and virtual image magnification.

key_concepts: The bending of light when it travels from one medium to another is called refraction.
Refraction occurs due to change in speed of light in different media.
The incident ray, refracted ray and the normal at the interface lie in the same plane.
questions: What is refraction of light?
Why does light bend at the boundary of two media?
State the laws of refraction.
What happens when light travels from a denser medium to a rarer medium?
Give one daily life example of refraction.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Refraction through a Rectangular Glass Slab
key_concepts: When light passes through a glass slab, it emerges parallel to the incident ray but displaced laterally.
The lateral shift depends on thickness of the slab and angle of incidence.
questions: Explain refraction of light through a glass slab with diagram.
Why does the emergent ray appear parallel to the incident ray?
What is lateral displacement?
State two factors on which lateral displacement depends.
Give an experiment to show lateral displacement.

key_concepts: Refractive index is the ratio of speed of light in vacuum to that in the medium.
It represents the extent of change in direction of light in a medium.
n = c/v, where c is speed of light in vacuum and v is speed in the medium.
questions: Define refractive index.
Write the formula for refractive index.
Why is refractive index of diamond very high?
Explain how refractive index determines bending of light.
What is the refractive index of water with respect to air?

key_concepts: Lenses are transparent materials bound by two spherical surfaces.
Convex lenses converge light rays, concave lenses diverge them.
Principal axis, optical centre, principal focus and focal length are important terms.
questions: What is a lens? Name two types.
Define principal focus of a convex lens.
What is the difference between convex and concave lenses?
What is meant by optical centre of a lens?
Explain focal length in lenses.

key_concepts: Convex lenses can form real or virtual images depending on object position.
Concave lenses always form virtual, erect and diminished images.
questions: Describe image formation by a convex lens when the object is at infinity.
What type of image does a concave lens form?
Draw a ray diagram for object placed between F and 2F of a convex lens.
Why are concave lenses used in spectacles?
Explain the nature of images formed by convex lenses.

subtopics.subtopic_name: Image Formation in Lenses Using Ray Diagrams
key_concepts: Rules: A ray parallel to the principal axis passes through the focus (convex) or appears to diverge from focus (concave).
A ray passing through the optical centre of the lens goes undeviated.
A ray passing through focus emerges parallel to the principal axis.
questions: State the rules used for ray diagrams in convex lenses.
What happens to a ray passing through the optical centre?
Draw a ray diagram for image formation by a convex lens when object is at F.
Why does a ray parallel to axis pass through the focus?
Explain ray diagram rules for concave lenses.

key_concepts: Object distances are taken as negative if measured against incident light.
Image distances are positive if measured in the direction of incident light.
Heights above principal axis are positive; below axis are negative.
questions: What are the sign conventions for lenses?
How is focal length taken for convex and concave lenses?
Why are object distances usually negative?
Give an example where sign convention is applied in lenses.
Explain the sign of image height in lenses.

key_concepts: Lens formula: 1/f = 1/v - 1/u.
Magnification m = h'/h = v/u.
Magnification positive → image erect, negative → image inverted.
questions: Write the lens formula and explain the symbols.
How is magnification calculated in lenses?
What does a negative magnification indicate?
Solve a numerical based on lens formula.
Differentiate between erect and inverted image magnification.

key_concepts: The power of a lens is the reciprocal of its focal length in metres.
Unit of power is dioptre (D).
Convex lens has positive power, concave lens has negative power.
questions: Define power of a lens.
What is the SI unit of power?
Why is power of concave lens negative?
How is power related to focal length?
If a convex lens has focal length 0.5 m, what is its power?

chapter_name: The Human Eye and the Colourful World

key_concepts: The human eye is an organ that enables vision.
Important parts: cornea, iris, pupil, lens, retina, ciliary muscles, and optic nerve.
The lens focuses light on the retina to form clear images.
The retina contains rods and cones that sense light and colour.
The ciliary muscles adjust the focal length of the eye lens to focus objects at different distances.
questions: Draw a labelled diagram of the human eye.
What is the function of the retina in the human eye?
Explain the role of the ciliary muscles in vision.
How does the lens of the eye focus light on the retina?
Name the parts of the human eye involved in controlling the amount of light entering.
Why is the cornea important for vision?

key_concepts: The ability of the eye lens to adjust its focal length to focus on near and distant objects is called power of accommodation.
The least distance of distinct vision for a normal eye is about 25 cm.
The maximum distance up to which the eye can see objects clearly is called the far point (infinity for a normal eye).
questions: What is meant by power of accommodation of the eye?
What is the least distance of distinct vision for a normal eye?
How does the ciliary muscle help in accommodation?
Differentiate between near point and far point of the human eye.
Why can't we see nearby objects clearly if the power of accommodation is defective?

topics.topic_name: DEFECTS OF VISION AND THEIR CORRECTION
key_concepts: Common defects: Myopia (nearsightedness), Hypermetropia (farsightedness), Presbyopia.
Myopia is corrected using concave lenses.
Hypermetropia is corrected using convex lenses.
Presbyopia occurs due to weakening of ciliary muscles with age and is corrected using bifocal lenses.
questions: Name three common defects of vision.
How can myopia be corrected?
What causes hypermetropia and how is it treated?
Why does presbyopia occur in old age?
What type of lens is used in bifocals and why?

topics.topic_name: REFRACTION OF LIGHT THROUGH A PRISM
key_concepts: A prism is a transparent optical element with flat polished surfaces.
When light passes through a prism, it bends twice: once on entering and again on leaving.
The angle between the incident ray and the emergent ray is called the angle of deviation.
questions: What happens to light when it passes through a glass prism?
Define angle of deviation in a prism.
Why does light bend twice in a prism?
Draw a ray diagram of refraction through a prism.
Give one daily-life example of light refraction through a prism.

topics.topic_name: DISPERSION OF WHITE LIGHT BY A GLASS PRISM
key_concepts: The splitting of white light into its component colours by a prism is called dispersion.
The band of seven colours formed is called the spectrum.
Red light deviates the least, violet light deviates the most.
questions: What is dispersion of light?
Name the colours of the spectrum in order.
Why does violet light deviate more than red light?
Draw a labelled diagram showing dispersion of white light by a prism.
Explain how a rainbow is formed in nature.

key_concepts: Atmospheric refraction is the bending of light as it passes through different layers of the atmosphere.
It explains phenomena like twinkling of stars and the apparent position of the sun during sunrise and sunset.
Stars appear to twinkle because of continuous refraction through varying air densities.
questions: What is atmospheric refraction?
Why do stars appear to twinkle?
Explain why the sun is visible a few minutes before actual sunrise.
Why does the sun appear flattened at sunrise and sunset?
Give one example of atmospheric refraction other than twinkling of stars.

key_concepts: Scattering is the phenomenon of light getting deviated from its path when it interacts with small particles of the medium.
The amount of scattering depends on wavelength; shorter wavelengths scatter more.
This explains blue colour of sky and reddish appearance of the sun at sunrise and sunset.
questions: What is scattering of light?
Why is scattering more effective for shorter wavelengths?
How does scattering explain the colour of the sky?
Why does the sun appear reddish at sunset?
State one difference between refraction and scattering.

key_concepts: The scattering of light by colloidal particles in a medium is called Tyndall effect.
This makes the path of light visible through a colloidal solution.
Examples: Blue colour of milk diluted with water, visibility of light beams in a foggy atmosphere.
questions: What is Tyndall effect?
Give two examples of Tyndall effect in daily life.
Why does a beam of sunlight appear visible in a dusty room?
Explain how Tyndall effect demonstrates scattering.
What makes the path of light visible in a colloidal solution?

subtopics.subtopic_name: Why is the colour of the clear Sky Blue?
key_concepts: The sky appears blue due to scattering of shorter wavelengths (blue light) by molecules in the atmosphere.
Blue light is scattered much more than red light due to its smaller wavelength.
At sunrise and sunset, the sun appears reddish because light travels longer paths and blue light gets scattered away.
questions: Why does the clear sky appear blue?
Which colour of light is scattered most in the atmosphere?
Why does the sun appear red at sunrise and sunset?
Explain why the colour of the sky changes at different times of the day.
What role does scattering play in the colour of the sky?

key_concepts: Electric current is the rate of flow of electric charges.
Current (I) = Charge (Q) / Time (t).
SI unit of charge: Coulomb (C); SI unit of current: Ampere (A).
Conventional current flows from positive to negative terminal, opposite to electron flow.
Ammeter measures electric current and is connected in series.
questions: What does an electric circuit mean?
Define the unit of current.
Calculate the number of electrons constituting one coulomb of charge.
A current of 0.5 A is drawn by a filament for 10 minutes. Find the total charge.
Why is the direction of conventional current taken opposite to the flow of electrons?

key_concepts: Electric current is defined as the rate of flow of charges.
Mathematically, I = Q/t.
questions: Define electric current.
What is the SI unit of electric current?
If 12 C of charge flows in 4 s, find the current.
How is electric current related to charge flow?
Who is the SI unit of current named after?

key_concepts: Conventional current flows from positive to negative terminal.
Electron flow is opposite to conventional current.
questions: What is conventional current?
Why is the direction of current taken opposite to electron flow?
In which direction do electrons flow in a circuit?
Which direction does a current arrow represent in diagrams?
How is the direction of current defined historically?

key_concepts: Ammeter is used to measure current.
It is always connected in series.
Current is measured in amperes, milliamperes, or microamperes.
questions: What instrument is used to measure current?
Why is an ammeter connected in series?
What are the smaller units of current?
How many electrons constitute 1 coulomb?
A 2 A current flows for 30s. Find the charge transferred.

key_concepts: Potential difference is the work done in moving a unit charge between two points.
V = W / Q, where V is potential difference, W is work, Q is charge.
SI unit of potential difference: Volt (V).
One volt = 1 joule per coulomb.
Voltmeter measures potential difference and is connected in parallel.
questions: Name a device that helps to maintain a potential difference across a conductor.
What is meant by saying that the potential difference between two points is 1 V?
How much work is done in moving a charge of 2 C across two points having 12 V potential difference?
How much energy is given to each coulomb of charge passing through a 6 V battery?
Why is a voltmeter connected in parallel in a circuit?

key_concepts: Potential difference is the work done per unit charge.
1 volt = 1 joule per coulomb.
questions: Define electric potential difference.
What is the SI unit of potential difference?
How much work is done in moving 1C charge across 5V?
Who is the unit volt named after?
What does 1 V mean physically?

key_concepts: Voltmeter measures potential difference.
It is always connected in parallel.
Cells and batteries provide potential difference.
questions: What instrument is used to measure potential difference?
Why is voltmeter connected in parallel?
What provides potential difference in a circuit?
What is the role of a battery in a circuit?
How is potential difference maintained in a closed circuit?

key_concepts: Circuit diagrams use standard symbols for clarity.
Common symbols: cell, battery, switch, bulb, resistor, voltmeter, ammeter.
Helps to represent complex circuits simply.
questions: Why are circuit symbols used?
Draw the symbol of a closed switch.
Draw the symbol of a voltmeter and explain its connection.
What does the circuit symbol for a resistor represent?
Explain the difference between crossing wires and a wire joint in a circuit diagram.

key_concepts: Each component has a unique symbol.
Examples: ⊕⊖ for battery, zigzag line for resistor, circle with V for voltmeter.
questions: Draw the symbol of a cell and a battery.
Draw the symbol for open and closed keys.
